section.title: A quick tutorial
section.para: The getting started section aims to get you using [[NAME]] in just a few minutes. This part helps you get it installed and run a demo. The next part looks at building and modifying some example applications, and final part take in-depth look at how a [[NAME]] is coded.

section.title: Installing [[NAME]]
section.para: Before we launch into using [[NAME]] you need to have the [[NAME]] binary distribution installed. This is covered in this section if you have not already installed it. There are other ways of building and running [[NAME]], but these are covered in later in the documentation in the main installation section.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: To build and run [[NAME]] applications for this tutorial you need Java version 1.5 or above, and Ant 1.7 installed on your machine. These can be downloaded from http://java.sun.com/ and http://ant.apache.org/ respectively.

section.title: Downloading the framework
section.para: The latest version of the [[NAME]] framework can be downloaded from the downloads page of the [[NAME]] Sourceforge project as shown below. For this tutorial you should download the binary release (suffixed with -for-ant) for immediate use. section.title: Running the Expenses demo application
section.para: The [[NAME]] distribution comes with a demonstration application for expenses processing i.e. for creating, submitting and approving expense claims. The application has only limited functionality - a real expenses processing application would require many more features - but what it has is realistic in terms of implementation.

There are two ways in which you can run the demonstration: as a standalone executable, or building it and running it from within a development environment. This chapter covers the former approach and looks at how a [[NAME]] application is used, while the next chapter looks at building and modifying the example allowing you to browse and modify the source code.
The files for running the demo can be found in the demo/expenses directory, while the source code and build files are in the examples/expenses directory.

When an application is started an application window is opened and the user's services are displayed on the left hand side. These icons typically give the user access to the domain objects held and used by the system, and provide a way for you to create new instances. Any other object that subsequently appears on the screen represents one of those domain objects.
The service and objects can be manipulated as follows:

listitem.para: Object actions can be invoked by right-clicking on an icon and selecting one of the options from the menu.
Service actions can be invoked by right-clicking on a service icon.
To inspect an object (when only an icon is shown) double-click it - this typically opens up the object in a new window.
Objects can be dragged by click-dragging on an icon and dropped by releasing the mouse button.

Dragged objects can be dropped on to an empty object field (identified by the grey hole; the label to the right of the hole specifies what type of object can be dropped). If the object can be dropped into that field then it will flash green. If the object cannot be dropped - either because it is the wrong type or that specific object is disallowed for some other reason - then the field will flash red. Dropping an object into a field sets up that field, effectively associating the two objects.

Dragged objects can be dropped onto other object icons. If the object that you attempting to drop onto accepts that type of object then it will flash green. If that object does not accept that kind of object, or disallows that specific object, then it will flash red. Dropping one object onto another invokes a specific object action, for example: add this product to that order.
To quit the application, or access other application related options right-click on the desktop to bring up the system menu.
Right-clicking on the border of a view (window or icon) will bring up the view menu, allowing the objects to be show in other ways.

In the same ways as for DND these links give the user access to the objects held and used by the system and provide a way to create new objects. Any other object that subsequently appears on the screen represents one of those objects.

For example if the Expense Claims link has been clicked on in the screen above and now shows the available service actions on the left hand side of the screen. Clicking on the first action brings up My Claims as shown below.

listitem.para: Object actions can be invoked by clicking on one of the options from the left hand menu.
Resource actions can be invoked by clicking on a service icon link in the resource bar and then clicking on a menu item from the left hand menu.
As objects are created or opened they are shown as links in an object history beneath the resource bar (the darker grey bar below the banner).
Similarly the current context, i.e. the current nesting of actions, is shown beneath the object history (the lighter grey bar).
